snippet: A project aimed at recapturing the soundtrack of history suggests that the rocks at Stonehenge were chosen, and hauled from a long distance, for their ability to produce hollow, bell-like noises.
abstract: Researchers have found that some rocks used to construct Stonehenge possess unusual acoustic properties; discovery, which was published in Time and Mind: The Journal of Archaeology, Consciousness and Culture, suggests that stones were purposely chosen for musical or acoustic purposes and presents theory for why they were transported 200 miles to site, significant technical feat at time.
lead_paragraph: A project aimed at recapturing the soundtrack of history suggests that the rocks at Stonehenge were chosen, and hauled from a long distance, for their ability to produce hollow, bell-like noises.

keywords.value: Time and Mind: The Journal of Archaeology, Consciousness and Culture
